Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Typical and atypical development of brain regions for Theory of Mind

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Our ability to reason about the thoughts of other people is the bedrock of our daily lives. Adults must think about others' thoughts constantly, from simple conversations to bluffing in a poker game. Even one-year-old babies learning their first words rely upon sophisticated inferences about the intentions of the speaker. Thinking about thoughts is ubiquitous, but it presents a serious cognitive and computational challenge. Prior research by Dr. Rebecca Saxe of MIT suggests that typical human adults achieve this feat partly by using a dedicated neural mechanism -- a group of brain regions that are recruited for thinking about thoughts. This CAREER award will pursue the implications of these results: How do specialized brain regions for thinking about thoughts develop in childhood? What role do these regions play in the social cognitive deficits observed in Autism? How is the development of these brain regions affected by changes in childhood experiences, such as delayed access to language? The proposed studies will investigate these questions by using behavioral tasks to measure development in children's ability to think about others' thoughts, and functional neuroimaging to measure concomitant development in the brain. The experiments will compare task performance and neural responses in typically developing children, children diagnosed with Autism, and children who experienced delayed exposure to language (e.g., deaf children of non-signing parents).

The research proposed here will generate new insights both within developmental cognitive neuroscience, concerning the structure and function of a fundamental domain of human cognition, and across disciplinary boundaries, addressing key questions in developmental psychology and neuroscience. The project may also help guide the translation of this basic research into interventions for children who are socially at risk. Additionally, the project will support the development of an elementary school neuroscience curriculum to bring the generated knowledge about children's developing brains back to the children themselves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human social life depends on the recognition that people’s actions are caused by unobservable internal states, like beliefs, desires, and motivations. Understanding other minds is a pre-requisite for cooperative social behaviours, like pedagogy and politics, and for competitive social behaviours, like deception. The capacity to reason explicitly about thoughts is called a ‘Theory of Mind’ (ToM). In human adults a group of brain regions are used particularly for ToM, collectively called “the ToM network.” In this project, we investigated how those brain regions develop over childhood. This question is important both to understand the brain mechanisms underlying healthy social development, and to suggest why some children struggle disproportionately with social interaction, including children with Autism Spectrum Disorders. 

 

In one major component of this project, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to measure brain activity in 122 children, aged 3 to 12 years, and 33 adults, while they watched a short, animated movie (Pixar’s Partly Cloudy). The movie depicts the relationship between a cloud, Gus, who makes babies, and his friend Peck, a stork who delivers the babies. The events depict changes in the characters’ bodily sensations (e.g. Peck being bitten by a baby crocodile) or desires and emotions (e.g. Gus feeling jealous when he catches Peck gazing at another cloud-stork relationship). The movie thus allowed us to measure spontaneous responses in children’s brains, while they are watching complex social events. 

 

In both adults and children, we observed that distinct networks of brain regions are recruited when the movie focused on the characters’ mind versus of the body. These networks are already functionally distinct in three-year-old children, but show increasing within-network and decreasing across-network correlations throughout childhood. The anti-correlation of the two networks strongly predicts the maturity of each network. Specific peak events within the movie evoke activity that increases with age, and with theory of mind reasoning ability. On the other hand, the most famous milestone in ToM behavioral development, passing explicit false belief tasks, does not correspond with a discontinuity in the neural basis for reasoning about the minds of others. 

 

Two other major goals of this project were: (1) to study the development of these brain regions within the life of individual children, and (2) to study the effects of language on the development of these brain regions. To pursue these goals, we have (1) tested a group of children on the same tasks twice, in two visits separated by one or two years, and (2) tested a group of d/Deaf children who learned sign language either as babies (from their signing parents) or as young children (in school). We are still analysing the results of these parts of the project. 


Finally, a major focus of our work was to teach young children and their families about the science of brain development. During this project, we did activities with thousands of children, both by visiting schools and community events and by inviting groups of children to visit our lab at MIT. One part of this outreach can be viewed in the Investigators TED(x) talks:

https://www.ted.com/talks/rebecca_saxe_how_brains_make_moral_judgments
